1.words: Okay, so really first, purpose of this conversation. So we really want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across different neighborhoods and different communities and really build an ecosystem of listening and trying to find a shared understanding and just creating a more inclusive and stronger Boston. So really to achieve this goal, that's why we invited you all here to engage in a new kind of conversation. So one about sharing personal stories, experiences, observations, things that you've seen maybe in your own lives, in your day to day, and really just focusing the conversation that way. So really we're just trying to build connections and facilitate that conversation for a deeper mutual understanding. And usually this comes through finding common ground on issues with public transportation and stuff like that. Secondly, it's really I want to address what's going to happen to the recording of the conversation. So following this conversation today, the audio recording is going to become a part of a collection of conversations. So this conversation, along with many others, are happening all throughout the city. So Real Talk at Boston is the team that's hosting this that's really manning this and they accumulated a 14 community based organizations, Boston Casa being one of them, and partnered every organization with MIT Center for Constructive Communication. And so really that's where the recording is going to. It's really just being part of a collective understanding of and also in a collection of other conversations that are happening across the city. Thirdly, all conversations that will be part of this effort will become part of the conversation platform that is developed by the non-profit organization, Cortico. And that's really MIT Center, it's their development arm. And so there it's called a fora system. And so they create a transcript of each recording conversation and that's what we do. We upload the recording and it creates the transcript and it really is meant to highlight common themes across different transcripts. So Jasmine and I go in and we highlight different parts of the conversation where we see major themes or something that's really standing out and it creates a system of keywords and then it creates patterns that way through the system. And then it's really about weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. And so this next part, I do have to say verbatim, so I always say that because it always sounds a little robotic. But as part of this conversation, you are providing consent to the MIT Center for Constructive Communication to retain the recording of this conversation in accordance with the mission of the Real Talk at Boston and transforming Boston into a listening city. You also understand that the conversation will be part of the Real Talk at Boston Public Conversation Collection with the goal to foster constructive conversations across the city. CCC will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that goal and with the mission to develop methods and tools that foster constructive communication in local communities. Participation in this conversation is voluntary and you can withdraw any time without consequences. Sessions will be recorded, but you can opt out and have this recording deleted. Only the research team at the MIT CCC will have access to your data. Your identity will be protected and information won't be shared without permission unless required by law. There are minimal for foreseen risk. However, with any conversation, there is a chance that you will hear stories that elicit strong emotions. We will support you in hosting a safe conversation where you can only share what you feel comfortable sharing. And then do you consent to this? And if everyone can just come off mute and just say, I agree.

And then do you consent to this? And if everyone can just come off mute and just say, I agree.
And then do you consent to this? And if everyone can just come off mute and just say, I agree.

5.words: All right. Also, and to say this, we want to make sure we have a chance for everyone to share and we learn from others in this conversation. So we really have a couple of guidelines. So make sure you speak for yourself and out of your experience, not your opinions. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Stay curious if you have questions, ask honest questions, if we pose a question and you need a time to reflect, pause and take that time and listen generously. We assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. If everyone thumbs up if those guidelines sound good. Okay. I'm going to kick us off with the round of introductions. You can share your first name. If you don't feel comfortable using your first name, you can use a pseudonym as well. And so Jasmine and I are, I'll just introduce Jasmine and I. So as the facilitators of this conversation, we're really here just to listen and to just guide the conversation, but really it's all on you all to share your experiences and just jump off of one another and be like, "Oh, I also agree and I experienced that same thing." But if you could share your first name or pseudonym and really just a story about your journey to Boston. So what brought you or your family here, whether that was recently or a long time ago, and what has your experience been like in the overall living in Boston? And anyone can go ahead and start us off.

6.words: I'll start off. My name is Kate. I'm a director of operations at a nonprofit organization. I've only been in Boston three years. This August I moved to Boston from Philadelphia because my husband got a job here in Boston. Prior to living in Philadelphia, I lived in Philly for five years and I lived in Chicago for 12 years, so I have lived in several of the major metropolitan areas in the United States. My general feeling, having been here in Boston now for three years is kind of mixed. It's a pretty city compared to some of the other metropolitan places that I've lived at. It is not my favorite place that I've lived, to be honest. So hopefully I can contribute to conversation since I've only been here three years.

7.words: My name's Andy, 65 years old, Massachusetts native. Having lived here my entire life other than the years I went to school. Is an administrator for a consulting company. My experience with Boston is generally positive. I haven't lived elsewhere so I can't really compare. Same time, I think Boston has some faults. I think I'm much older than the rest of you. I was in high school when the busing was implemented in Boston. A very ugly situation. Racial relations are better, but they're not good. Economics, probably similar to the nationwide, divide between the wealthy and the less wealthy just keeps growing and government could run better. You could say the same thing about academia and private business.

8.words: Ana, I moved to Boston seven or eight years ago and transferred to a high school here for a parent's job and then I ended up staying in Boston for four years of undergrad and now I'm in medical school in Boston. So I've experienced the city mostly from the student's perspective and while as someone who's interested in medicine, it offers a lot of opportunities and it's really wonderful in that way. I've also learned a lot about the more I get into the system of there are faults as other people mentioned, and while it's a very progressive state for practicing, there's also a lot of huge gaps that still need to be addressed.

10.words: Hi, Dr. Sherry. I lived in Boston when I went to Emerson College and I am actually a professor and I teach at Fisher College and I taught at Emerson as well and I find that I appreciate that we can walk pretty much to many spots. It's easy to get around. I enjoy taking the ferry from East Boston to the north end and walking through the Boston Commons and the gardens. I enjoy many aspects of Boston and we have everything here. We've got hospitals and restaurants and colleges and people come from all around the globe to visit here. It's very cultural. We have a lot of entertainment. I just find this is a wealth of opportunities here if you reach out and hopefully you can experience all the opportunities that we have here.

12.words: Okay, I'll say this, I'm sorry. It is tough being in East Boston when it comes to transportation because if they're working on the tunnel and that's closed and after working on the bridges and that's closed and so it does get a little tricky, but I do appreciate, as I said, we have the ferry and it's easy to get right on to Maverick station and get right into town. The T stops are pretty fairly quick, but it can get challenging. Traffic is unbelievable in East Boston, especially at certain times, but I find that we are lucky that we do have a transit system. There are places that don't have those opportunities and it is easy to walk around once you're in town as well, as I said earlier. So that's transportation.

10.segment_words: it is easy to walk around once you're in town as well, as I said earlier.

13.words: Thank you. Does anyone else have a time they'd want to share about when they felt supported by their community in Boston?

11.segment_words: when they felt supported by their community in Boston?
11.linked_words: a specific time or moment where you felt supported by your community here in Boston

14.words: I volunteered for the team on Marathon Day for a couple of years now, and there's obviously a lot of thoughts and feelings about ways to improve equity in the marathon in general, but from the perspective of just being a volunteer supporting on race day, I've had some of the best experiences with people who have come back to the city just to volunteer, flowing from other coasts, other countries to come back and volunteer for that day. It's a really wonderful display of pride for the city and to see you get grouped with nine people who you're working with all day long in a pretty high-paced, high-stress situation and just function as such a cohesive team and take care of runners and then consider these people like friends at the end of the day, I think. So the lot about the strength of some of the communities in the city.

15.words: I wanted to mention too, and I should have said this, is that I appreciate when we're all welcome to. So when the mayor has the trolleys during the holiday season and goes to every single Boston town, and I appreciate that they've been trying to incorporate all of us into more activities. However, there was in Maverick Square they built this, I don't even know what it's called, so it's like a tent, but it took a lot of parking away and being able to park to these local businesses is very important and I think that they could have did a better job at communicating with the residents and the businesses to see if that's what we actually wanted in our community. As I said, I think it's nice to be incorporated, but it's something you should be asking us if that's what we want because it's taking away parking. I like to go to Cindy's Nails and get my nails done or go to the Spinelli's with my grandson to get him some pizza and we can't park anywhere because they have this huge, they took up this huge little parking lot that's great for folks who have to come and go and need to get in and out of local businesses. And I just wanted to say that I appreciate being incorporated and being included, but I would talk to the residents and the business to see that that's actually what we want and if that's the section of town that we really wanted it.

13.segment_words: I just wanted to say that I appreciate being incorporated and being included, but I would talk to the residents and the business to see that that's actually what we want

17.words: Yeah, I mean in terms of support, it's hard. Like I said, I've only been here for a few years. A couple of things that I can think of offhand though. I know the mayor does do her coffee talks or whatever in different neighborhoods, which two summers ago I happened to just wander in. She came to a park, I live in South Austin, she came to a park there and that was really nice to see because they had all the different community organizations and they had free coffee and Dunkin' Donuts and the dogs were there and that was a really nice aspect of just feeling like I wasn't there long enough for her when she was actually there, but it was nice to get to interact with all the different community groups and people were there, which was really nice. One thing that I did that's not specific, it's specific to my community, not necessarily support to me was one of, recently this last summer, one of the small shops, like a cute little gift store bottle shop in our neighborhood was robbed during the summer. Somebody came in, took their cash, whatnot, and it got posted on social media and it got shared throughout the neighborhood, all the neighborhood sites and all the different businesses. And we had gone in to see them because we go in there pretty frequently and we had talked to them and they said that they, it was like the day or two after, that they had had the biggest day of sales that they'd had and their history. I think they've been there like three years because everybody in the community was worried about them because they had gotten robbed and obviously, or small business and income could be very tight. And she said everybody in the community came out and when we had gone in there it was jam packed. People were just in there buying things, supporting them, which I thought that was really cool. I think South Boston, at least my experience where I live and the street, is kind of transient, there's a lot of young college kids that live, there's a lot of young people that are moving out. So it can feel not very neighborhoody sometimes, but that was one of the moments where it did feel very supportive community because everybody was coming out to support these small business owners.

13.segment_words: A couple of things that I can think of offhand though.

22.words: I can go ahead and share first. In general, I mean I acknowledge I am in a very privileged position in my life, so a lot of the things that are common worries I'm not affected by to that extent because of the privileged position I live in. The things that I worry about though in terms of the city are a lot of things like Andy mentioned, the economy, supporting people. Obviously housing, affordable housing is a huge issue right now. The housing prices are just coming up. I came from Philly where there was a severe obviously issue with unhoused individuals who were experiencing substance abuse issues. Same thing here. And that issue with the bulldozing sites and moving people and displacing people without having solutions. For me, I saw it in Philly. I see the same thing here. I just saw a friend who's in, I think Sacramento, where they're doing the same thing where they're just going, the city's going in and just basically totally eliminating these sites for unhoused individuals without any support or plans for what they do. And all these issues are interconnected and I have yet to see any really viable solutions in really any of the cities I live in for the problem. But those are the kind of things that I think I worry about.

21.segment_words: The things that I worry about though in terms of the city are a lot of things like Andy mentioned, the economy, supporting people. Obviously housing, affordable housing is a huge issue right now. The housing prices are just coming up.
21.linked_words: so it's okay if the answers bleed over. But it's more the next question we want to pose is tell us about a worry maybe you have about a day to day while living in Boston. And this can be related to anything.

23.words: I would just, as what Kate was saying when it comes to housing and affordability and I mean a lot of Bostonians had to move out of where they grew up because they can no longer afford. And especially I know many families in East Boston that they can't afford. I mean it's so difficult now to even afford getting a home, let alone just getting an apartment and trying to make ends meet. So I would definitely say the economy is tough to juggle everything and it's sad to see homeless people as well. It's very troubling and yeah.

25.words: I can repeat what I said earlier. I'm actually a very negative person. I would suggest most of society has problems in most elements. I think housing really is the biggest issue. Factors on economics, they're interrelated. Pretty sad that we can housing our neighbors and this is a nationwide issue. But I don't have a solution. My policies are pretty far to the left. I'm in favor of social services, government activity, higher taxes, but that's not an opinion shared by the majority of our citizens.

26.words: For what it's worth, I agree on all those things. The solutions are, a lot of the solutions lie with things that a lot of individuals in the society do not want to ante up. I would happily pay more taxes if it meant that we could provide more social services to individuals in need. But like Andy said, a lot of people don't feel that way.

27.words: No, thank you for sharing. Anna, do you want to say anything or add anything to that?

24.segment_words: Anna, do you want to say anything or add anything to that?

28.words: Yeah, I mean I can echo a lot of the same things like Kate said, from a more privileged standpoint, even being so as a student, it's just insane the cost of housing and it's still sometimes less than university housing. It's really difficult to find. I've rented for pretty much six years now and it's impossible to not have a job while being in school full time. But that is still from a privileged position and I've seen and learned from working in emergency rooms and things like that, how huge of a problem it is for everybody at a lot of different income levels. But especially not having such a basic need, how there's so much like unused space in the city that could be used to provide the most basic needs that would trickle down into them being able to find jobs and be healthier and be a part of the community that they deserve the chance to do. Not just with native Bostonians, but also I've learned a lot about how, this is not my personal experience, but I've had personal experience seeing how this plays out where people who are immigrating, like families and a lot of the political priorities have shifted to not being able to just provide even an emergency shelter. So I think it really, like everybody else said, runs all ends of the spectrum from students who are a lot more fortunate to people who need it the most and yet it's the same problem.

30.words: Well, as someone that's a little older that's been around for a couple of decades, I have seen Boston change, but what's most important is the historic, that they keep the integrity of the historic aspects. Although I wouldn't be against them redoing city hall, that's probably one building that we could probably redo and be happy about. But we are so blessed with the richness of the culture and the buildings and people just love the details that we have. And so I wouldn't want to really change that even though I know we are going environmentally safe and environmentally structured, but I still think that we need to keep the integrity of our history of our buildings and how beautiful they are and intact. I'm not really sure what I would be looking for, although obviously when we talk about diversity and maybe accessibility for those who have wheelchairs and it's not always easy even though we are getting better, there's buildings that I know that if you're four floors, you don't have elevator but five floors you will. So that doesn't help those that still need to get up the first four floors. And I don't know, we're moving more into virtual rooms too, so cutting back on even going into buildings or even going into offices. So I'm not sure what the future holdings help, but I never want to go to the moon, so don't ask me to go to the moon. I'm not going with you.

32.words: Repeating on the themes earlier, one thing I hope the city would continue to advocate for is the conversion of office space that no longer needed. A layperson perspective it would seem, it should happen quicker than it is, but for us that we're downtown, even in the neighborhood I'm in, there's empty space. We should put financial resources, having those converted to housing and maybe that's something that will actually, must agree, occur in the next decade.

33.words: I want to bring up parking, specially living in East Boston. There's no parking. I have to pay 225 to park in the garage that I live at. So when these builders come, they should be providing more parking. I'm not necessarily thinking we should have to pay for parking, but it is concerning because there's really nowhere to park and I don't want to try to figure out at night, I'm too old to be looking around for a spot, but it's really difficult. I can't even really have my daughter come visit me because there's really nowhere for visitors to park, let alone residents. So if there's any way to work on parking, I would definitely say the more we build these places, we should be providing parking, whether it's downstairs of a garage, that we need more parking. There's just nowhere to park in the city and I don't think that we should go not having cars. I know that that's like a thing that they want us to just take bikes and not all of us can ride a bike and I'm not going to put my grandson on my shoulders. I'm not going to put my bags all away. So we want to be realistic as well. And obviously I understand the environmental issues, but we want to be realistic and cars are here, so. Back to you.

34.words: Yeah, I mean I certainly hope that they improve the public transportation system here in Boston. I know that they're working on it. I've taken public transit and almost entirely in both the cities that I've lived in previously. And it by far is the worst in general here in Boston. It should be accessible. It's a small city, it shouldn't be this difficult. I walk to work two miles every day because I can walk as fast as I could probably get from the red line into work. I don't mind, it's obviously good exercise, but it's silly that it should be a 20-minute ride in. But the times that I've taken it's just been delays and obviously there's delays right now and I know a lot of people, especially if you're living outside of the city trying to get into Boston, it's terrible. So I hope in 10 years that they make it more accessible. I know we won't get rid of cars completely, but I do hope the city makes it easier. I know they're putting in a lot of bike lanes, which come with a lot of mixed feelings about because they do take parking away. But I do hope they invest in some of the infrastructure for people to be able to bike and to take public transit so that we can realistically get away from having cars. I know that it's not possible in the way the city's set up right now to try to be car-free, which is I think where they have to think about. You can put in as many bike lanes as you want, but unless and encourage people to bike and take public transit. But if your system isn't great, nobody's going to do it.

37.words: I personally, it was nice to hear from Dr. Sherry about East Boston. I've been to East Boston one time in three years and I want to go there more, but it is hard to get to with the tunnels and if you're sort of isolated over there, I need to take the ferry over. And I think it's nice to hear from everyone that we all are on the same page about a lot of issues, but it's nice to hear from people who don't. I work in the north end, I live in the south and I admit I haven't even in three years really traveled too much around Boston. So I need to remind myself to do that more so I can experience the city a little bit more.

38.words: Yeah, I will say this, there's so much to do in Boston. Something's always happening. Like I said, there's the culture, there's the museums. I do like that they're trying to incorporate all Boston students being able to go to the museums. However, I'm also a grandma and my grandson stays with me on the weekends and I appreciate being able to bring him to the museum. So I'm hoping that they even stretch that out to residents of Boston, meaning that because I'm a resident, I could take my grandson. Now, I do take him and I get the passes of the library. I know they reduced, but I want to say that the children's museum is like $11 a piece. So even having him, I mean I'm certainly not going to go climbing on the things that he does. I'm just basically watching him do that. But I think that they could reduce it for grandmas too. But I want him to get all the culture he can get. It'll be great. But there's so much here to do. I mean, like I said, everyone comes from around the globe. I have friends that are coming from Australia that I'm meeting them tomorrow, where they're going to come visit the Boston. You have to go through the Boston Commons, you have to go through the Gardens, walk the Freedom Trail, and it's all here. It's just all here. But maybe we need to make it even more aware that it's all here. We do because we have the best schools, we have the best hospitals, we have all the restaurants, all the cultures come here. I mean there's a lot of greatness here. We're like the smallest city in the United States, we're like the metropolis. So definitely come to east, they love us.
